questions.question: What core question does neuroscience aim to answer?
questions.feedback: Neuroscience asks how brain activity gives rise to behavior.

questions.question: Which systems are studied in neuroscience?
questions.feedback: Neuroscience studies both central and peripheral nervous systems.

questions.question: Which disciplines contribute to neuroscience?
options: Biology, psychology, physics, engineering, and philosophy
questions.feedback: Neuroscience is an interdisciplinary field.

questions.question: What is the primary functional unit of the nervous system?
questions.feedback: Neurons are the basic units that process and transmit signals.

questions.question: What is the main function of neurons?
questions.feedback: Neurons send electrical signals over short and long distances.

questions.question: Neurons are described as electrically and chemically excitable because they:
options: Generate electrical signals and release chemicals
questions.feedback: Neurons use both electrical and chemical signaling.

questions.question: Which neuronal component primarily receives incoming signals?
questions.feedback: Dendrites are the main targets of incoming synaptic signals.

questions.question: What is the role of dendritic spines?
questions.feedback: Spines increase the surface area for synaptic contact.

questions.question: What is the primary role of the cell body (soma)?
questions.feedback: The soma integrates signals from dendrites.

questions.question: Which structure contains the neuronâ€™s DNA?
questions.feedback: DNA is stored inside the nucleus.

questions.question: Genes are best described as:
questions.feedback: Genes are DNA sequences that encode instructions.

questions.question: Proteins are composed of:
questions.feedback: Proteins are chains of amino acids.

questions.question: Why are proteins described as the working molecules of the cell?
questions.feedback: Proteins carry out most cellular processes.

questions.question: Where are action potentials typically initiated?
questions.feedback: The axon hillock is the trigger zone for action potentials.

questions.question: What property makes the axon suitable for long-distance signaling?
questions.feedback: Axons conduct electrical signals over long distances.

questions.question: What is the effect of axon myelination?
questions.feedback: Myelination increases conduction speed.

questions.question: What is the function of the presynaptic terminal?
questions.feedback: Presynaptic terminals release neurotransmitters.

questions.question: Neuronal communication is described as dual because it involves:
questions.feedback: Signals travel electrically along axons and chemically at synapses.

questions.question: Which example best illustrates structure influencing function?
questions.feedback: More dendrites allow a neuron to receive more inputs.

questions.question: Why is neuron diversity important?
options: All neurons perform the same task
questions.feedback: Neuronal diversity enables specialized functions across the nervous system.
